body:
> There are 5 other references to homosexuality in the Bible, both old and new testament, all implying it is sinful.

Sodom & Gomorrah doesn't even comment about it, nor does Ham's story, nor are either of these God's words. We're left with 2 supposed references by Paul in his actual letters, which are also not God's words. One is almost certainly incorrect, the other (Romans 1) is still uncertain, was probably added later, *and* it's part of a larger passage which is likely Paul quoting someone else judging by the way chapter 2 starts. The others are 1 Timothy, which is also very unlikely to be correct, and also not actually written by Paul. The last supposed one is Jude, which is also not God's own words; and it says "different flesh" not "homo", because if you recall the Sodomites were trying to rape the angels. The whole Jude passage is about angels too.

> In the end, the context makes it most clear. A convoluted interpretation which claims gay buttsex is OK as long as you don't do it lying down in a woman's bed (in which case, it's abominable and punishable by death) doesn't really make much sense... especially when you consider all the other verses which also allude to the sinful nature of homosexuality.

It was more likely a scribal error because the sentence is actually nonsensical. If it was written as it stands, it was probably something to do with menstruation laws, or even doing it in the bed of a "burnt offering" which is the same word as "woman", and sexual acts were a common way of worshipping pagan gods in ancient times. As for the death penalty, that was unlikely actually prescribed; it's pretty obvious that Leviticus 18 was written first and that Leviticus 20 copies it, adding the legal penalties which largely go against God's nature. And even Leviticus 18 has been modified.

> When I was younger, I also believed that a loving God wouldn't mind who we had sex with, but I grew out of that phase. Now I understand that our father's rules may seem mean and unfair, but we each are guilty of breaking them, (myself worse than many others) and, the main thrust of grace is to repent of our sins, not proudly declare we did nothing wrong.

You had genuine insight when you were younger, but "grew out of it" because your social conditioning did its job, and your brain developed further. The human brain is tribalistic and attracted to mean leaders, because it creates a strong collectivist culture and you feel safe and protected by them. It's similar to how a lot of women want a mean boyfriend, because he looks more capable. But Jesus repeatedly denounces both bad laws and made-up laws.

> The obvious and traditional explanation for why these extra words were necessary is that the verb שכב literally means “lying down”, and its use for sex is metaphoric or euphemistic. Under that explanation, those extra words are to clarify that we are talking about sex here, not about lying down.

This is incorrect. שכב is not used to describe sex. As a verb it always means lie. As a noun, it almost always means bed. So here, literally, "lie beds".

> The word “משכב” is used in other places in the Bible for a bed, but in other places it is used for the act of lying down or even as a euphemism for being sick. So the interpretation that those two words mean “as you would a woman” is not unfounded.

So they're just going to say it *isn't* used for sex anywhere else and that's somehow evidence that's what it means. "Lie lyings of a woman" doesn't make sense either.

> So these two interpretations are equally valid and supported by the text:
> 
> Don’t f--k a man Don’t f--k a man as you would a woman OTOH “Don’t f--k a man on a woman’s bed” just doesn’t make enough sense to be considered valid."

The first one is not valid because it is not in the text. It is, at best, a guess. And based on what we know about before the Romans took over Christianity, that guess is probably wrong.
body_html:
There are 5 other references to homosexuality in the Bible, both old and new testament, all implying it is sinful.

Sodom & Gomorrah doesn't even comment about it, nor does Ham's story, nor are either of these God's words. We're left with 2 supposed references by Paul in his actual letters, which are also not God's words. One is almost certainly incorrect, the other (Romans 1) is still uncertain, was probably added later, and it's part of a larger passage which is likely Paul quoting someone else judging by the way chapter 2 starts. The others are 1 Timothy, which is also very unlikely to be correct, and also not actually written by Paul. The last supposed one is Jude, which is also not God's own words; and it says "different flesh" not "homo", because if you recall the Sodomites were trying to rape the angels. The whole Jude passage is about angels too.

In the end, the context makes it most clear. A convoluted interpretation which claims gay buttsex is OK as long as you don't do it lying down in a woman's bed (in which case, it's abominable and punishable by death) doesn't really make much sense... especially when you consider all the other verses which also allude to the sinful nature of homosexuality.

It was more likely a scribal error because the sentence is actually nonsensical. If it was written as it stands, it was probably something to do with menstruation laws, or even doing it in the bed of a "burnt offering" which is the same word as "woman", and sexual acts were a common way of worshipping pagan gods in ancient times. As for the death penalty, that was unlikely actually prescribed; it's pretty obvious that Leviticus 18 was written first and that Leviticus 20 copies it, adding the legal penalties which largely go against God's nature. And even Leviticus 18 has been modified.

When I was younger, I also believed that a loving God wouldn't mind who we had sex with, but I grew out of that phase. Now I understand that our father's rules may seem mean and unfair, but we each are guilty of breaking them, (myself worse than many others) and, the main thrust of grace is to repent of our sins, not proudly declare we did nothing wrong.

You had genuine insight when you were younger, but "grew out of it" because your social conditioning did its job, and your brain developed further. The human brain is tribalistic and attracted to mean leaders, because it creates a strong collectivist culture and you feel safe and protected by them. It's similar to how a lot of women want a mean boyfriend, because he looks more capable. But Jesus repeatedly denounces both bad laws and made-up laws.

The obvious and traditional explanation for why these extra words were necessary is that the verb שכב literally means “lying down”, and its use for sex is metaphoric or euphemistic. Under that explanation, those extra words are to clarify that we are talking about sex here, not about lying down.

This is incorrect. שכב is not used to describe sex. As a verb it always means lie. As a noun, it almost always means bed. So here, literally, "lie beds".

The word “משכב” is used in other places in the Bible for a bed, but in other places it is used for the act of lying down or even as a euphemism for being sick. So the interpretation that those two words mean “as you would a woman” is not unfounded.

So they're just going to say it isn't used for sex anywhere else and that's somehow evidence that's what it means. "Lie lyings of a woman" doesn't make sense either.

So these two interpretations are equally valid and supported by the text:

Don’t f--k a man Don’t f--k a man as you would a woman OTOH “Don’t f--k a man on a woman’s bed” just doesn’t make enough sense to be considered valid."

The first one is not valid because it is not in the text. It is, at best, a guess. And based on what we know about before the Romans took over Christianity, that guess is probably wrong.

guild.description: Got a burning unpopular opinion you want to share? Spark some discussions!
guild.description_html: Got a burning unpopular opinion you want to share? Spark some discussions!
guild.name: UnpopularOpinion

parent.body:
Like I said,  I've heard this more than a few times before,  and read more than a few rebuttals to this line of logic (None of which are apparently promoted in Google's search results any longer... *interesting* that.  I'll try to find links to them to when I don't have obligations pressing on my time. )

Absent those, I'll suggest a couple points to consider. 


-Nowhere in the Bible is there an example of condoned homosexuality. 

- There are 5 other references to homosexuality in the Bible, both old and new testament,  all implying it is sinful. 

Obfuscation by a handful of *progressive, revisionist* scholars to subvert the simple intent of the law doesn't hold much weight IMO.

In the end,  the context makes it most clear.  A convoluted interpretation which claims gay buttsex is OK as long as you don't do it lying down in a woman's bed (in which case, it's abominable and punishable by death) doesn't really make much sense... especially when you consider all the other verses which also allude to the sinful nature of homosexuality. 

When I was younger,  I also believed that a loving God wouldn't mind who we had sex with,  but I grew out of that phase.   Now I understand that our father's  rules may seem mean and unfair, but we each are guilty of breaking them, (myself worse than many others) and, the main thrust of grace is to repent of our sins,  not proudly declare we did nothing wrong. 

Oh yeah,  and to love and forgive our brothers and sisters no matter what.  77 times if we have to.  

As I said earlier,  and I maintain now again: I do not condemn God's gay children, my own sins are enough for me to worry about.   I abhore legalism and embrace grace, praise God. 

***I did find an interesting rebuttal I read on Quora from a Hebrew translator.  It is the first response to this thread https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-specific-meaning-of-Leviticus-20-13

"You make some interesting points. However, I think there are a few points you are missing about the Hebrew text.

The verb used is a direct verb (“את זכר לא תשכב”) unlike the verbs used in both English and modern Hebrew which are indirect as in “sleep with”. This is significant in that it shows a totally different concept of what sex is. In the Bible sex is something that a man does to someone else, usually a woman. That is why adultery in the ten commandments is sleeping with another man’s wife, and why nothing is ever said (until the Talmud) about Lesbians — women don’t do sex, they have sex done to them.

So the phrase is obviously directed at the male reader and directs him not to sleep with a male. If that was the extent of the verse, it would be quite clear. But then they had to go and qualify this with the “משכבי אישה”.

The obvious and traditional explanation for why these extra words were necessary is that the verb שכב literally means “lying down”, and its use for sex is metaphoric or euphemistic. Under that explanation, those extra words are to clarify that we are talking about sex here, not about lying down.

The word “משכב” is used in other places in the Bible for a bed, but in other places it is used for the act of lying down or even as a euphemism for being sick. So the interpretation that those two words mean “as you would a woman” is not unfounded.

So these two interpretations are equally valid and supported by the text:

Don’t f--k a man
Don’t f--k a man as you would a woman
OTOH “Don’t f--k a man on a woman’s bed” just doesn’t make enough sense to be considered valid."
parent.body_html:
Like I said, I've heard this more than a few times before, and read more than a few rebuttals to this line of logic (None of which are apparently promoted in Google's search results any longer... interesting that. I'll try to find links to them to when I don't have obligations pressing on my time. )

Absent those, I'll suggest a couple points to consider.

-Nowhere in the Bible is there an example of condoned homosexuality.

  • There are 5 other references to homosexuality in the Bible, both old and new testament, all implying it is sinful.

Obfuscation by a handful of progressive, revisionist scholars to subvert the simple intent of the law doesn't hold much weight IMO.

In the end, the context makes it most clear. A convoluted interpretation which claims gay buttsex is OK as long as you don't do it lying down in a woman's bed (in which case, it's abominable and punishable by death) doesn't really make much sense... especially when you consider all the other verses which also allude to the sinful nature of homosexuality.

When I was younger, I also believed that a loving God wouldn't mind who we had sex with, but I grew out of that phase. Now I understand that our father's rules may seem mean and unfair, but we each are guilty of breaking them, (myself worse than many others) and, the main thrust of grace is to repent of our sins, not proudly declare we did nothing wrong.

Oh yeah, and to love and forgive our brothers and sisters no matter what. 77 times if we have to.

As I said earlier, and I maintain now again: I do not condemn God's gay children, my own sins are enough for me to worry about. I abhore legalism and embrace grace, praise God.

***I did find an interesting rebuttal I read on Quora from a Hebrew translator. It is the first response to this thread https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-specific-meaning-of-Leviticus-20-13

"You make some interesting points. However, I think there are a few points you are missing about the Hebrew text.

The verb used is a direct verb (“את זכר לא תשכב”) unlike the verbs used in both English and modern Hebrew which are indirect as in “sleep with”. This is significant in that it shows a totally different concept of what sex is. In the Bible sex is something that a man does to someone else, usually a woman. That is why adultery in the ten commandments is sleeping with another man’s wife, and why nothing is ever said (until the Talmud) about Lesbians — women don’t do sex, they have sex done to them.

So the phrase is obviously directed at the male reader and directs him not to sleep with a male. If that was the extent of the verse, it would be quite clear. But then they had to go and qualify this with the “משכבי אישה”.

The obvious and traditional explanation for why these extra words were necessary is that the verb שכב literally means “lying down”, and its use for sex is metaphoric or euphemistic. Under that explanation, those extra words are to clarify that we are talking about sex here, not about lying down.

The word “משכב” is used in other places in the Bible for a bed, but in other places it is used for the act of lying down or even as a euphemism for being sick. So the interpretation that those two words mean “as you would a woman” is not unfounded.

So these two interpretations are equally valid and supported by the text:

Don’t f--k a man Don’t f--k a man as you would a woman OTOH “Don’t f--k a man on a woman’s bed” just doesn’t make enough sense to be considered valid."

body: It seems like you're looking at the text having already decided what the meaning is. In reality it's literally "And with a male you shall not lie beds of a woman". Nothing more or less, that's what it says, and the lack of a linking word between lie and beds is not a typo. The Septuagint, the earliest translation, renders it this way, indicating that's how it was understood. There are plenty of sexual condemnations in that chapter but no other instance describing sexual intercourse in the *entire Bible* uses the words of this one. The only reason it seems obvious to you is because of your culture and the current controversy over that particular issue. It's at the front of your mind, and you see false positives. Someone who'd never heard of this before would not get the same impression as you do.
body_html: It seems like you're looking at the text having already decided what the meaning is. In reality it's literally "And with a male you shall not lie beds of a woman". Nothing more or less, that's what it says, and the lack of a linking word between lie and beds is not a typo. The Septuagint, the earliest translation, renders it this way, indicating that's how it was understood. There are plenty of sexual condemnations in that chapter but no other instance describing sexual intercourse in the entire Bible uses the words of this one. The only reason it seems obvious to you is because of your culture and the current controversy over that particular issue. It's at the front of your mind, and you see false positives. Someone who'd never heard of this before would not get the same impression as you do.

parent.body:
Torturing the text and ignoring the most obvious translation: "bed the way one beds a woman"....

I understand you don't like it,  but it simply is what it is.  A descriptive euphemism with obvious meaning.  To bed... Bedding.  However,  not "sick" bedding,  or "tired" bedding, but "to bed the way one does with a woman," as it clearly says in the text. 

It's really plainly obvious,  unless you are trying to not see it, because,  feels.

Regardless,  we've descended into gridlock here.   I'll pray for patience and wisdom,  and,  certainly forgiveness if I am wrong about this.  I don't condemn the sinner, he is welcome to sit in the seat of honor before me.  I have my own problems.
parent.body_html:
Torturing the text and ignoring the most obvious translation: "bed the way one beds a woman"....

I understand you don't like it, but it simply is what it is. A descriptive euphemism with obvious meaning. To bed... Bedding. However, not "sick" bedding, or "tired" bedding, but "to bed the way one does with a woman," as it clearly says in the text.

It's really plainly obvious, unless you are trying to not see it, because, feels.

Regardless, we've descended into gridlock here. I'll pray for patience and wisdom, and, certainly forgiveness if I am wrong about this. I don't condemn the sinner, he is welcome to sit in the seat of honor before me. I have my own problems.

body: Ronald Reagan was okay. The Republican party could by no means be considered fascist until suddenly a year ago when they flip flopped their entire ideology except their "morals". Prior to that they always championed limited government and only allied with traditionalists because the Democrats wanted (and still want) to erase their way of life.

body: Conservatives are *supposed* to be conserving the Constitution, rights, etc. That is not for or against Christianity although it did have a lot of Christian support, but politics was separate aside from Democrats trying to destroy Christianity. Conservatives aren't supposed to be "conserving" traditions by forcing them on everyone with governmental power, which is completely against their original ideology. Sometime last year either they suddenly changed their minds or the timeline got screwed up. And that's when all these fake Christian movements merged with them. Progressives have pretty much stayed the same, although the main difference is now morals instead of ideology since they have both now agreed on a strong, totalitarian state that controls every aspect of peoples' lives and crushes dissent and nonconformity.
body_html: Conservatives are supposed to be conserving the Constitution, rights, etc. That is not for or against Christianity although it did have a lot of Christian support, but politics was separate aside from Democrats trying to destroy Christianity. Conservatives aren't supposed to be "conserving" traditions by forcing them on everyone with governmental power, which is completely against their original ideology. Sometime last year either they suddenly changed their minds or the timeline got screwed up. And that's when all these fake Christian movements merged with them. Progressives have pretty much stayed the same, although the main difference is now morals instead of ideology since they have both now agreed on a strong, totalitarian state that controls every aspect of peoples' lives and crushes dissent and nonconformity.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:
This is just one way out of several to explain revelation. We can not say that this is the only right one. If you look at the world around us, I see this whole fake pandemic as a rehearsal for the final domination of world under one government, and the introduction of antichrist. On that site, everything is explained as symbols, but in reality you don't have to use any symbols to see it. People are being restricted from restaurants, shops, cinemas, for not being vaccinated on bigger and bigger scale. For now we don't have anything in our hands, or on forehead (and I personally think that this vaccine is not the sign of the beast, though I saw people who think so) but that might be a thing of two-three years until chips are given into people's body with everything about them. Moreover, that site doesn't say a thing about the false prophet, and the punishments obviously didn't happen yet. Not to mention that 'soon' doesn't really mean anything. It doesn't specify the time. Jesus said he will return soon. In that case, soon is at least 2000 years. 

Other thing that points to the 'last days' being near is the stuff, that is talked about on SuspiciousObservers channel (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rEv3HRIVPUQ). What is soon about to happen to our Sun and Earth is literally described in Revelation in one of the seals (Revelation‬ ‭6:12-17).  I think though that to understand this video, it is needed to check out other content on that channel.
parent.body_html:
This is just one way out of several to explain revelation. We can not say that this is the only right one. If you look at the world around us, I see this whole fake pandemic as a rehearsal for the final domination of world under one government, and the introduction of antichrist. On that site, everything is explained as symbols, but in reality you don't have to use any symbols to see it. People are being restricted from restaurants, shops, cinemas, for not being vaccinated on bigger and bigger scale. For now we don't have anything in our hands, or on forehead (and I personally think that this vaccine is not the sign of the beast, though I saw people who think so) but that might be a thing of two-three years until chips are given into people's body with everything about them. Moreover, that site doesn't say a thing about the false prophet, and the punishments obviously didn't happen yet. Not to mention that 'soon' doesn't really mean anything. It doesn't specify the time. Jesus said he will return soon. In that case, soon is at least 2000 years.

Other thing that points to the 'last days' being near is the stuff, that is talked about on SuspiciousObservers channel (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rEv3HRIVPUQ). What is soon about to happen to our Sun and Earth is literally described in Revelation in one of the seals (Revelation‬ ‭6:12-17). I think though that to understand this video, it is needed to check out other content on that channel.

although I do think it will be introduced in some kind of unexpected way because many of us are aware and awake as to what an obvious mark would look like

guild.description:
Ask and answer questions.

Rules:

🤔 Posts must be questions. This is a community dedicated to Q&A discussion, so post titles must be in the form of a question.

⁉️ No loaded questions.

📬 No spamming. Spamming comments or posts is not allowed.

😀 Be civil. Be nice. Harassment, trolling, and disruptive behavior is not allowed. Basically, don’t be a jerk.

🥾 Breaking these rules will result in posts being kicked and possibly an exile.

📜 Follow Ruqqus ToS. This is a given.

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

body: They do. But women are not shamed for it, and will be taken care of by family, a husband, or the government, and everyone supports them. Men almost never will. Most girls in school went into fun majors because they're not expected to have a serious job for making money, because someone else will do it for them. The boys usually have to choose something they don't exactly love but it makes them a living. (This is the real reason for the huge gender gap in STEM subjects). Women have all the options. Men are forced onto a specific path for the most part, and usually not an overly exciting one.
body_html: They do. But women are not shamed for it, and will be taken care of by family, a husband, or the government, and everyone supports them. Men almost never will. Most girls in school went into fun majors because they're not expected to have a serious job for making money, because someone else will do it for them. The boys usually have to choose something they don't exactly love but it makes them a living. (This is the real reason for the huge gender gap in STEM subjects). Women have all the options. Men are forced onto a specific path for the most part, and usually not an overly exciting one.

parent.body: Women get just as much shame for living with their parents just as men. It doesn't matter, they're both leeches who need to get a job.
parent.body_html: Women get just as much shame for living with their parents just as men. It doesn't matter, they're both leeches who need to get a job.

post.body: There is a lot to be said about being independent... but there is nothing wrong with living with those you love.
post.body_html: There is a lot to be said about being independent... but there is nothing wrong with living with those you love.
post.title: Young adults should not be shamed for living with their families

body:
> until they lose it

Nope. You respect everyone whether they're good to you or not. Even some of the most evil people respect those who respect them.
body_html:
until they lose it

Nope. You respect everyone whether they're good to you or not. Even some of the most evil people respect those who respect them.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

guild.name: Christianity

post.body:
How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect? 

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.
post.body_html:
How does one honour those who dishonour you? I would say that everyone is entitled to basic respect until they lose it, but entitlement to high respect is a concept I struggle with in the faith. And what of earning respect? Am I owed respect?

Speaking of, does the text refer to respect, generally being nice, or that I as child, owed to them as parents? Asking as per the definition of honour, according to Google, which implies that all 3 completely different meanings can apply depending on context.
post.title: Struggling with Commandment #5 - "Honour your father and mother."
